item.title: Year 2: February
item.description:
February was quite a wild ride.

The Technical side Link to heading

I really learned a ton of things here: In January, I focused on preparing samples for transport measurements while in February, I (re) learned how to do all the experiments I did in the past: Magnetization, transport (on a rotator), heat capacity, and even PXRD. Remembering the basics and how each one fits into a puzzle helped me figure out what I was looking for. There are a few things I have learned.

item.title: Year 2: January
item.description:
And we’re back! Came back from almost a month break during which I played Taiko in LA, went to Ohio, and got covid… so no science. Popped back in and hit the ground running pushing projects and getting used to doing research full time.

It feels great being able to accomplish and read things but it feels as if I run around all day making things happen and have one hour of concentrated work a day. I’ve been talking to Ryan Day, a postdoc in the Analytis group, and we both agree that we just need to start our computations before we arrive to work… which happens to be 8 or 9 am. Oof.

item.title: Year 2: November
item.description:
I felt like I really got some momentum back in my research. A little late but a few highlights:

  • Restarted DFT calculations and getting into computational condensed matter

  • Started a Topological Order Reading Group with Kai and other friends in my year

  • Got to know my mentors and got closer to other research group members.

  • Decided to stick with James for my Phd

  • Finished up being a TA for Physics 141A: Solid State physics with Joe Orenstein

item.title: Year 2: October
item.description:
Some quotes I enjoy.

  • ‘‘I don’t like integrals’’

  • Open a bottle when you win a grant. Drink every time something in the experiment fails.

  • Some weeks are just sad weeks. Whoops.

  • Writing an NSF proposal: Me to my advisor: ‘‘Is this even true?’’ My advisor: ’’ Probably’’

I finished a reading course on Quantum Info Meets Quantum Matter by Xiao-Gang Wen along with a few friends that gave me a first glance into topological order. While it fills me with wonder and curiosity, it is also sad as to the state in which we can observe it in real life. No amount of theory can help that as much as experiment. This helped me make the decision to stop my rotation with Professor Zaletel and work again with Professor Analytis. One of the reasons why I rotated in the first place was to see if I enjoy doing theory research.

item.title: Year 2: September
item.description:
Academically Link to heading

This month, I spent my time doing a rotation with Mike Zaletel. I looked into Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG) method and topological order in the fractional quantum hall effect. I started to see how computationally nice one dimensional models are, how computationally hard two dimensional models are, and how hard three dimensions is. It fills me with a little sadness to know how hard it is to model three dimensional models. Density functional theory (DFT) seems to be our best bet and even then it is hard to reliably predict using DFT. In fact, even if DFT is wrong its hard to diagnose what happened and most just shrug and say you used the wrong pseudopotential…not very helpful :(
